Erich Haubrich
Mar 15

Healthcare During the Trumpocalypse

If you are a supporter of Trumpcare (AHCA) please tell me why. What changes are actually happening that can be considered positive or a move in the right direction? Please provide some facts so I can try to see it the way you do.

Here’s the thing: I’m just not clear on how kicking 14 million people off of medicaid and giving enormous tax breaks to extremely wealthy people could possibly be an improvement on Obamacare (ACA). ACA is broken, but so far all I’m seeing in the replacement is an enormous money grab for big money donors and insurance companies.

The right-wingers are talking about AHCA being focused on ‘Patient Care’ and ‘Choice’ — In fact, the only way in which it addresses choice are forcing the elderly and poor to choose between food and medicine.

Rolling Stone Article Excerpt — The Shocking Verdict on Trumpcare…
“Trumpcare — the House legislation the president has claimed as “our wonderful new Healthcare Bill” — will kick tens of millions of Americans off the insurance rolls and slash Medicaid by nearly $900 billion. That’s the verdict of the Congressional Budget Office, the nonpartisan scorekeeper charged with forecasting the impact of new legislation.
Trumpcare not only covers fewer people, but will also drive up premiums — at least in the short term. According to the CBO, Trumpcare will drive a spike in insurance costs of 15 to 20 percent for those who remain in the individual market.
“AHCA retains part of the provision regarding pre-existing conditions…sort of…but allows insurers to raise rates due to PCs…so no big deal…if you don’t mind paying ridiculous premiums.”
“…The blows of Trumpcare hit hard and hit early. By 2018 alone, “14 million more people would be uninsured,” compared to continuing Obamacare, according to the CBO report. By 2020, Trumpcare would reverse all the progress the country has made in expanding insurance under Obamacare — stripping 21 million of coverage. But Trumpcare isn’t done. By 2026, the damage swells to 24 million. That’s like kicking every man, woman and child in the state of Texas off America’s insurance rolls.”
“Under Trumpcare, insurance becomes unaffordable for many. CBO lays out the case of a 64-year-old with an annual income of $26,500 in the year 2026. Under Obamacare, the government would pay the vast majority of that person’s $15,300 premium, leaving the lower-income near-retiree on the hook for just $1,700 in insurance costs, for a policy that covers 87 percent of care.”
“Under Trumpcare, this 64-year-old gets hit three ways. First, Trumpcare allows insurers to charge this person five times what it charges a young person. (Obamacare limits this ratio to 3-to-1.) Second — and this is the big whammy — the Trumpcare insurance tax credit is capped. The government covers only $4,900 in premiums. That leaves the individual on the hook for $14,600 in policy payments. Third, the insurance is worse: The CBO report predicts the policy will only cover 65 percent of the cost of care…. Just paying the premiums would leave this wage-earner with less than $1,000 a month to pay for life’s other necessities, and unable to afford co-pays should he or she get sick.”
Link to Rolling Stone Article

Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) are not like insurance, BTW. They are just your own pre-tax dollars, which you can save and then pay for your own healthcare. That’s great, but my most recent visit to the ER totaled up to $9,632.67. That was prior to being admitted to the hospital for a couple of days…so let’s just round up to $20K — are you currently saving that kind of money…or would you rather just have viable insurance?

Buying prescriptions from other countries? We can already do that, and the prices are lower in many cases. Do you know why that is? It’s in part because the Republicans passed a law making it illegal for Medicare to negotiate prescription drug prices. (In 2014, Medicare spent $143 billion on drugs, and total sales for the pharmaceutical industry surpassed $317 billion.)

The ability to buy insurance across state lines is not what it looks like on the surface. Have you ever noticed that a lot of credit card companies and banks are located in South Dakota? That’s because they have virtually no regulations regarding lending practices and consumer protections….What do you think is going to happen with insurance companies? They will flock to whatever state allows them to abuse customers.

The Mandate is another topic that deserves a look. Currently there is a small tax penalty for people that decide that they do not want to buy insurance, but would rather just use the ER at taxpayer’s expense when they get sick. It is based on the tax year and whether or not you had insurance coverage. There are reasons that this makes sense (low-risk patients offsetting costs for high-risk patients, etc.), and also reasons why it’s flawed. Here’s the kicker…Under Trumpcare the mandate is somewhat disguised. If you drop your insurance coverage for longer than two months you will not have a tax penalty, you will just have to pay 30% higher premiums to your insurance provider. Remind me how that benefits anyone besides private insurers.

All the talk of repeal and replace with a better system is a half ton of horseshit. This is a money grab, and a not very well thought out money grab at that. If the Republicans were doing their job as lawmakers and not just shilling for their donors I’m fairly certain we’d start to see some real solutions emerge, but we have become lax and stupid, money has taken over politics (and now your health) and we’re all going to be watching people in our country die and suffer unnecessarily.

A big question I have is the following:
Why is it that we cannot figure out a single-payer system? I feel like the answer is that there would be no way to funnel billions of dollars to Wall Street and wealthy donors (on both sides of the aisle) if we put a single-payer system together. Big Pharma would also have a lot harder time ripping us all off on medicines.

Please feel free to send me your hate if you choose, but really…What is it that you find appealing about this new plan? What do you feel this does to make our country a better place and provide a better future for us all? I’d sincerely love to know.
